goal.en: Neuroeconomics is a combined topic involving psychology (the study of behavior), neuroscience (how the brain and nervous system work), and economics (the interaction between people and value, typically of goods or services). Investigation of these areas in combination aims to give a better understanding of economic decision making, why certain choices tend to be made, and what factors can influence these, all in the context of understanding the neural basis of the decisions themselves. The course will aim to give insight into these topics and the brain functions that relate to them, including evolution of decision-making, social decision-making, decision-making under risk, effects of emotion on decisions, and how the brain represents subjective value.

content.en:
Introduction to neuroeconomics
Brain anatomy and function
Brain models of decision making and choice
Neural representation of subjective value and choice value
Affective mechanisms of decision-making
Dual process theory of decision making
Decision making under risk
The social brain
An evolutionary perspective
